p: When pathogens are endemic, for example, MRSA or Clostridium difficile in healthcare facilities, it can be difficult to decide whether one or more outbreaks are under way or whether there has simply been a general rise in the incidence of infection. Eyre and colleagues [ 25] showed that bench-top sequencing of whole bacterial genomes could be used in near real time to confirm or refute the existence of outbreaks of MRSA or C. difficile in an acute hospital setting. In particular, they found that the genome sequences from an apparent cluster of C. difficile infections turned out to be unrelated and so did not represent an outbreak sensu stricto [ 25].
